transcripts.text: Merry Christmas, everybody.  I know this is a very different Christmas than we're used to, but it is a time to still greet each other, to see each other, and to celebrate each other.

And I know everyone has their traditions that they normally do each year, and they're going to be different this year.  I know we have our tradition.  We have our famous brunch that we do with our family and we're not going to be able to do that this year where i know you love making your mom's recipe for chili relleno and i know we're not gonna be able to do that this year.

no i'm gonna do it dougie i'm just gonna make it a lot smaller.  but yeah no we can't.  there's so many families are having the same experience of.  you know it's.  um It's going to be a much smaller situation.  And I think about all of the families who also are going to have, like Joe says, an empty chair at the table because of someone they've lost.
The food lines we're seeing all over the country.  Right.

And so many people who become unemployed.  Right.  how they're going to be able to buy gifts for their children.  But this is a time to celebrate Christmas.  We celebrate the birth of Jesus.  We celebrate the hope of this moment.  It's the spirit of knowing the power that we each have to leave the world better than we found it.
We're thinking, too, of the frontline health care workers who are just putting their lives on the line right now for us, aren't they?

And our military service members.  So many people.  And, you know, our thoughts, of course, and our prayers go to them with thanks.  And so we're going to get through this moment and we're going to get past this moment.

And we know that it's not going to be like this.  And next year at this time, I strongly believe that we're all going to be together and celebrating and just enjoying those same traditions that we always have, right?  Yes.
And have a happy new year, too.
